review_title: Healthy work environment, career growth is actively discouraged
job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: -great benefits -friendly coworkers -rewarding work
cons: -growth is actively discouraged -many departments are mismanaged -mentorship is deprioritized

job_title: Associate Producer in New York, NY
pros: The office was centrally located.
cons: I worked in the film division of the larger research institute, it’s a small operation. It could be credited to it being a newer company but there were high levels of disorganization, toxic work environment, unfriendly staff, and low levels of support as a new employee. The workload for the position was insane and included many things not advertised in the initial job posting (after I left, the position I held was divided into multiple positions, which told me everything I needed to know). It was clearly a start-up environment with a generally overwhelming lack of direction, vision, and organization that fell onto the plate of lower level employees. Barely any respect for diversity/inclusion beyond surface level platitudes and bragging rights at HR meetings which was uncomfortable on top of it being an all-white space. Salary did not match the work load or demand from lower level employees. Overall, typical toxic film industry environment with unrealistic expectations, little diversity, poor communication, and coldness/lack of internal camaraderie and communication among the staff.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great work environment, Great benefits and perks!
cons: Could try to promote from within the company more

review_title: Do yourself a favor and move on.
pros: Free food and no real deadlines or expectations. Work here if your career is not a priority and you want to leave at 5 on the dot. Everyone raves about the benefits but most companies these days have the same or better benefits packages. Great benefits don't make up for low salaries and absolutely no career growth.
cons: You will never get promoted. Your manager either doesn't care about your career trajectory or doesn't have the power to promote you. Leadership is comfortable and absolutely will not rock the boat or advocate for you in any way. They are mostly concerned about keeping their own comfy jobs and paychecks. (Those in leadership are paid well- others are not.) You absolutely cannot trust the HR department- they only care about their own interests and those of the foundation. They will never reprimand anyone in leadership, even if it's completely warranted. There are no consequences for bad actors in leadership roles. It's them against you. The HR dept needs a complete overhaul and should be reprimanded and investigated for its practices.

job_title: Flatiron Research Fellow in New York, NY
pros: - Total freedom in your research - Amazing benefits (equivalent to companies like Google or Meta) - Seminaries in various scientific fields - Even if it is young, it is becoming quite prestigious - In the very heart of Manhattan, with housing at discounted rates in Greenwich Village - Very low pressure at work - Ties with nearby universities (NYU, ...) - No teaching
cons: I can't think of any cons, this is the perfect place to do research in a very dynamic environment.

job_title: Research Fellow in New York, NY
pros: Good near-academic environment with corporate-style staffing and perks
cons: Fairly disorganized on the inside, like a university, but still better

review_title: wonderful place to do a postdoc
pros: Smart colleagues, lots of freedom, generous travel budget, amazing benefits relative to other postdocs
cons: Flatiron Institute is still very new, and it sometimes seems like it hasn't quite found its identity/strategy yet

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Simons Foundation was a wonderful place to join a few years ago. The health benefits are incredible. The mission is one anyone can feel proud of. There are a lot of nice people.
cons: Marilyn Simons is no longer the CEO, unfortunately. The CEO is disconnected with staff unless their area is of interest (at least thats how it felt to me). They make decisions from a pedestal, only sometimes pretending to hear the opinion of others. The office is beautiful, but the divisions among departments and teams are incredibly hard to breach, which is so unfortunate. There is little room for growth. When anything goes wrong, they love to knock someone down as an example and ignore the true problem, which is often far more complicated.

pros: -Free medical, dental and vision for employee and dependents -free breakfast, lunch and healthy snacks -Nice office space - Annual company trip - lots of opportunity for training (job related and non job related) -Pay
cons: - work from home one day a week (Monday or Friday) - no kids or pets in office

job_title: Associate Research Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Great environment to just focus on computational research with lots of opportunities to do public outreach.
cons: Not really a con but if you want to advance in research you must have a PhD.

pros: The foundation really takes care of its employees with a great health plan and excellent benefits package. It has the benefits of a startup, but also with great work/life balance.
cons: You can find better salaries elsewhere. No bonuses.

pros: friendly, supportive, great benefit, great retirement pay

pros: great benefits, beautiful facilities, healthy and positive company culture

pros: don't go here if you're promotion driven, but you can learn and grow your career in different ways.
cons: can be slow moving and organizationally challenged.

review_title: Great place to work if you never want to get promoted within the company
pros: Benefits, fair pay, work community, work environment.
cons: No promotions, light raises, controversial decision making during multiple world and local health crisis.

pros: If you are a mathamatians, this is a heaven.
cons: If you are not into hardcore math, don't bother.

pros: High quality people, great computing resources, funding
cons: Lack of graduate students, some departments not yet fully staffed

pros: The Simons Foundation is a great place to work--in general, people are professional and kind, and there are good structural supports in the place. There are many opportunities to learn by attending various lectures and programs. Employee learning is encouraged and there is a generous 401k and donation matching program. Good work-life balance overall.
cons: The salaries are lower than similar jobs at other places. Very traditional in some ways--WFH is not allowed more than one day a week. Company-wide, there is a bit of a trend of complacency--people do get spoiled and the pace of things can feel slow at times.

review_title: Great benefits, culture leaves something to be desired
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Overall good work/life balance (excluding the WFH policy), supportive and smart colleagues, excellent benefits & perks.
cons: It's not a bad place to work, but over time the lack of career advancement, blatant favoritism, and division between scientific and administrative staff wears on you. There is almost no WFH flexibility, which leaves staff feeling untrusted and micromanaged. One's experience seems to be based a lot on who you know or who your manager is.

pros: the flexibility of research and learning different topics
cons: no WFH options and must stay in NYC

job_title: Project Manager in New York, NY
pros:
The underlying mission of the Simons Foundation is inspiring, and employees can see that few members of the organization really does care about the happiness and well-being of the employees. The facilities and benefits are top notch.

The work and pace can be challenging, but there is adequate balance provided to employees.
cons:
Senior management has actually stated that this is not a place for people to grow. Career opportunities are hard to come by. 

For an organization that wants to pride itself in promoting basic science and mathematics, management is really averse to making data-driven decisions. 

Favoritism runs rampant, with hand-picked individuals in roles. There are a number of intelligent individuals employed by the organization, but unfortunately not many actually have management skills. There is a distinct lack of management, structure and oversight to promote working more efficiently.

Informatics has no clear vision; and bad management led to staff leaving, or requesting to transfer to another team. The informatics team is a cesspool filled with handpicked individuals not qualified to actually manage.

job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in New York, NY
pros: Being the face of the company is a plus. The benefits are out of this world
cons: One of the few staff needed on site during almost times of the year.

job_title: Flatiron Research Fellow in New York, NY

review_title: Fab job and a great learning environment
job_title: Web Developer in New York, NY
pros:
It's really nice to go to work at a place where important work is getting done
Professional development is prized and strongly supported
Life / work balance is highly respected
The life of the mind here is fantastic (lectures, very smart people, exposure to all kinds of knowledge and experience)
I mean, really, we support and do some amazing work and learning about it all never stops being fascinating
Lots of institutional support for improvement and growth
Great benefits and perks (like matching contributions to 501(c)3s, which is amazing!)
cons:
There are a lot of meetings
Sometimes, the Foundation grows faster than its infrastructure

pros: Full of incredibly smart and varied people. There are very few places doing privately-funded research like this in the world. Decent benefits for an academic institute. They do a good job at making sure the foundation has enough events that it feels like a community.
cons: Anyone joining from outside academia is in for some culture shock. Various parts of the buildings have been under construction for a long time and that work can be distracting later in the day.

pros: Great pay and benefits (especially the company 401K match), free company trips, paid lunch and company-provided breakfast daily and interesting research topics.
cons: The staff seems like a cult worshipping the company's philanthropic leader. What a weird group of people (there were a few exceptions). And add to that the camera surveillance was the most intense I've ever seen. One employee, in particular, was annoying and a constant nuisance.

pros:
Lunch is paid for
Educational seminars
No budgetary constraints
Nice office
cons:
Projects are  mismanaged at the top and the lack of strategy/money wasted is demoralizing to work around. Hiring more bodies is not a way to encourage success. Time to change it up in terms of top level management.

Salaries are below average. Most would rather pay for their lunch than not be paid their worth.

There is a lot of favoritism. 

Most are in at 10am and out by 5pm. This is not a place that will push your work ethic.

pros: Excellent employee benefits, beautiful offices
cons: Low morale, toxic, bad management

pros: Free lunch, lots of food, free snacks. Some good colleagues.
cons: From the outside it seems like a dream organization to be a part of. Once inside it's very toxic.  Very disappointing. You're either shut up and get with the program or speak up and get dismissed.

pros: Amazing benefits, amazing and genius group of people. Lots of trust and opportunity to grow.
cons: Salary is decent but not quite competitive.

pros: Most importantly, amazing, motivated, helpful and talented people are working here. You can really grow in such an environment. Lots of perks including free lunches and competitive salary.

pros: Extraordinary benefits, fully stocked kitchen
cons: Knowing that the founder, Jim Simons, is Robert Mercer's business partner (Renaissance Technologies). Confrontational management, obsession with changing technologies every other week, working in a hermetically sealed bubble closed off to the real world. Progress is measured by volume of paper.
